There are three ways there could be a new King in Saudi, but odds of each are low:
1. Salman dies. But he is in good shape physically. He is likely to live around 10 years, leaving about a 1% chance he could die in the next month or so, with MBN presumably replacing him. 
2. Salman is overthrown. We again put this as a low chance with MBN being the presumed replacement. 
3. Salman steps down. Another 1% chance but this time with MBS as the most likely named successor.

I don't believe there will be a new King of Saudi Arabia before June 1st, because the Saudi Arabian kingdom has never transitioned from one generation to another, and no one is certain of what the outcome will be.

Last week, John Kerry "was received" by the King before moving on to a working meeting.  If the King has Alzheimer's Disease, as rumors suggest, this announcement may have importance.   Death from Alzheimer's is usually preceded by a period where your condition deteriorates to the level where it wouldn't make sense to for you to be receiving anyone, even in a courtesy ceremonial event.  The fact that Kerry "was received" suggests the end may not be imminent, making it a little more likely perhaps that this question will time out.
Short of a stroke and/or sudden death of any sort, no changes will happen in the succession to the throne.
At this point you would need a sudden illness that has not been previously telegraphed as being an issue, which leaves me to believe that health with not be an issue for the next 2-3 months.
Raising slightly because time is running out for any of these unlikely events to happen.

If some thing happens to the king in theory his son would be king . It's the usual tribal decision if the son  has shown promise. I am not sure it would be a good idea if  he abdicates to his son.
If he gets sicker he may abdicate , but he seems to be ok for now.

I'm basing this prediction on the rationale that radical change driven by the monarchy is not consistent with the plan of change we've seen so far.  The plan of change appears to be to diversify the economy away from dependence on oil exports.  The implementation even goes so far as efforts to increasingly pass the cost onto its own citizens though the Prince has said there are no taxes, that VAT is not a tax on the people.  And, we also see the idea of taking Aramco public. I believe the audience is being played.  Their government has maintained a strong stance with regard to countering opposition through such actions as executions.  I could go on but would I just be gathering data to support a model that I've already accepted? If I'm wrong, I'm wrong.  That's the nature of prediction.  Oftentimes, the prediction is not what it seems but rather a certain aspect of the overall prediction holds true with the result that the perception of the questioner changes.

Finally report and analysis from Sputnik with some juicy gossip! http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20160202/1034088377/saudi-palace-coup-analysis.html Russians are excellent analysts of imperial dynamics and conspiracies, although they do tend to get into video game territory.

The current King may be demented but there are good reasons why various parties might want to prop him up in a corner and keep him around for a while.  This is not a simple succession struggle between MBN (CIA favorite) and MBS (youth gone wild).  This is a complex conflict among powerful family factions and the stakes are high.  The continuing existence of the House of Saud could be on  the line.  Succession is only the proxy question.  Reaching consensus on an effective strategic vision for Saudi Arabia is the real question.  Rumors about a quick succession quicken the pulse.  But it seems more likely that the difficult internal argument about the real question will run on for a while.  Having the current King in place, allows this pushing and pulling to continue.

In the US, President Wilson's wife ran the country for rather a while after he was debilitated by a stroke, and everybody politely kept quiet about it.  That was then and this is now, but that was the US then and this is Saudi Arabia now.   After all, I am almost completely out of it and I have no intention of giving up my kingdom.  (Wait--I'm being told I don't have a kingdom.  Never mind.)

I've been very low on one end of the see-saw with this question for quite some time, originally going with a base actuarial analysis that the current king had a good chance of surviving until June and the strange arrangement of power sharing would be maintained.  I know the rumor of an imminent transition (weeks) may be bogus disinformation.  However, many aspects of the situation in Saudi Arabia have deteriorated with surprising rapidity.   I fear the notorious black swan is now circling over the House of Saud.  I wouldn't be a bit surprised to see the regime collapse entirely and decamp to the Cote d'Azur, although maybe not before this question times out.

I don't see a coup by 1 June as likely. Despite reports of the King's deteriorating health, he looks very good in appearances with China's Xi and Pakistan's Sharif, he'll hold on for another 4.5 months.

I hadn't thought of the possibility that the ultimate source of this story is Iran, but it certainly makes sense. As @AndrewSabisky points out, changing the rules of succession would cause a great deal of bad blood in the Saudi royal family, and possibly some real trouble. However, the link that @seveDB provided (here: http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/the-most-dangerous-man-in-the-world-a6803191.html ) indicates that Mohammad bin Salman is well positioned to distribute patronage, thus filling the bureaucracy with his supporters. As for buying support in the royal family, I find that perfectly credible. Here's  the Wikipedia page, for what it's worth: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Saud Note that "The family is estimated to be composed of 15,000 members, but the majority of the power and wealth is possessed by a group of only about 2,000." And I'm sure distribution of power and wealth among those 2,000 isn't equal. So I'm sure a lot of Saudi royals can be bought off. Buy off enough of them, and you can change the rules of succession, since most of those 15,000 pope don't have a shot at succeeding to the throne anyway.

"We've been told to expect changes in the summer"

As I said, it's going to be a hot Summer. Maybe it happens sooner rather than later. I'm going up a bit more on Salman to go along with the general panic. I haven't convinced myself the timing is right, but what do I know of anything there, especially his health.

To date, the only source is this one: http://www.gulfinstitute.org/exclusive-saudi-king-to-abdicate-to-son-2/ Other news outlets, including from Iran, just cut-and-pasted the reporting of Ali al-Ahmed, a Saudi critic of the monarchy. He started his own think tank, based in Washington, D.C. I know nothing about him or whether he is reliable or not. My first impression is that he sounds legit. Ali al-Ahmed on twitter: https://twitter.com/AliAlAhmed_en?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor
On NPR: http://www.npr.org/2016/01/15/463146189/u-s-must-normalize-its-relationship-with-saudi-arabia-expert-says & http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2013-10-28/challenges-saudi-arabia-home-and-abroad The rumors of abdication are just that. Rumors should not be taken at face value (obviously). I remember in previous seasons the Palestinian sources in Ramallah who said that test results were in and showed that Arafat was not poisoned by polonium. Wrong. Or Dan Rather reporting that a trusted source inside Hugo Chavez's inner circle said he was on his death bed. Except he wasn't. Chavez did die, but six or seven months later. At the same time, there could be something to the rumors. If they are true, I doubt King Salman would abdicate if it meant that Mohammed bin Nayef would succeed him. So, I'm giving a low probability to bin Nayef while not ruling out the possibility. We're all flying blind on this one.

I've not seen any corroboration of the news stories of King Salman about to step down. @AndrewSabisky makes a good point about Iran being the source of these rumors. OTOH, the King is likely suffering senile dementia, basically serving as a place holder while the princes scheme and plot.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/93504 What makes me move on this is that I'm getting the feeling that Summer 2016 is going to be unusually hot in the Middle East. If you're planning a war, you don't want to be dealing with royal succession in the middle of it. Nayef, we are told, has been side-lined and is perhaps a bit too moderate (dovish) for the war-mongering set. There may be some perceived need to lock-in Salman the Younger if he is more aggressive and pliant. On the other hand, this would seem like an extremely hard sell to the household at-large. "A" war (against ISIL, etc.) is not "the" war (against Iran), so for that, and other (mostly timing) reasons, I'm going to stay cautious for now.

http://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1901033/dangerous-game-young-saudi-prince-heart-middle-easts-great-power-struggle " . . . the young Saudi deputy crown prince, [Mohammed bin Salman] who, at just 30, has had a conspicuous ascension since the coronation of his father, King Salman, last year. "Mohammed bin Salman not only has the defence portfolio, but has also assumed responsibility as Saudi Arabia’s chief economic planner, a vital task given the perilous effect that a slide in global oil prices has had on his nation’s economy. There are rumours that the current crown prince, Mohammed bin Nayef, 56, could even eventually be moved aside for Mohammed bin Salman. "Unsurprisingly, the prince’s rise has caused ripples, and has antagonised some other members of the vast royal House of Saud who resent being shunted aside by the younger generation. Moreover, the prince and his father have presided over a pronounced - and, to some, worrying - shift in the kingdom’s role on the world stage. . . .  to “the aggressive policy role played by Mohammed bin Salman,” seen most keenly in the largely derided Saudi war effort in Yemen. .  . [which] has spiraled into a protracted battle and led to a crippling humanitarian crisis.
. . . 
There is more widespread concern, though, in the destabilising effect of Saudi Arabia's own actions. Both in the United States and Europe, a frustration with the kingdom is growing. In an unusually blunt memo distributed to journalists last month, Germany's chief intelligence agency, the BND, warned of the dangerous ambitions of King Salman and his son, who they claimed aspire to be “leaders of the Arab world.” “The previous cautious diplomatic stance of older leaders within the royal family is being replaced by a new impulsive policy of intervention,” the BND said.  Old assurances have given way to a new, uncertain dynamic. “There is also a sense that Prince Mohammed is an inexperienced gambler who is likely to double his stake when his bets fail,” writes veteran journalist Patrick Cockburn. “This is the very opposite of past Saudi rulers, who had always preferred, so to speak, to bet on all the horses.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This piece describes how other nations view Mohammed bin Salman.  If this is accurate--and I have no specific reason to doubt it--then I'd say that Western government  operatives will not be working behind the scenes to facilitate the transfer of power to Mohammed bin Salman.

http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/inquirer/disquiet-in-the-house-of-saud-as-oil-price-plummets/news-story/5e6d49bfd0c970805b184c521219cf87 "During the past couple of decades there has been a minor industry prophesying the imminent fall of the house of Saud. Every year some new book or article would argue that Saudi Arabia’s rulers were about to be overthrown. Every year these prognoses have been proven wrong.
. . . 
"Until recently, there has been good reason to be sceptical of analyses predicting the collapse of the house of Saud. Often such analyses ignored the enduring foundations of Saudi rule: the ruthless determination to stay in power that kept family rivalries in check; the alliance with the Wahabbist establishment that provided the house of Saud with religious legitimacy; and the world’s deepest reserves of oil that allowed Riyadh to buy loyalty and to fend off adversaries. "Much of the “coming fall” Saudiology was also based on the thin data and voluminous rumours that still surround one of the least transparent regimes in the world. To really know Saudi Arabia is to admit that you really don’t know that much. However, in recent years the fuzzy outlines of the family’s prospective demise have suddenly become a little sharper.
"The customary cautious, consensual approach of Saudi princes is not going to win Mohammed bin Salman the throne. 
. . . 
" . . . .if troubles abroad complicate and challenge Saudi policymaking, it is problems at home that really matter. Sometimes external and internal challenges coincide. 
. . . 
"Rivalries in the family are nothing new. What is different this time is the lack of a clear line of succession, which raises the stakes. The customary cautious, consensual approach of Saudi princes is not going to win Mohammed bin Salman the throne. . . . "One anecdote provides some insight into the prince’s ambition. Just after he became Defence Minister, a Saudi-watching friend of mine showed me a digital photo doing the rounds. It was an image of Mohammed bin Salman that after a few seconds dissolved into a picture of the founder of the Saudi state, Ibn Saud, highlighting the similarities in their physical and, by implication, other features. "Quite what Mohammed bin Nayef can do about this is not clear. Some speculate he is biding his time, giving the young prince enough rope to hang himself. But what gives the rivalry added ­piquancy is the oil price problem. Some of this is Saudi Arabia’s own doing. It has refused to cut oil production, keen to preserve its market share and deliver an economic poke in the eye to rival oil producers in Russia and Iran, as well as to the shale oil wildcatters of the US. The costs of this policy are rising. Saudi Arabia is not about to go broke, but that is not the point. Saudi Arabia’s oil wealth funds the highly subsidised, little-taxed lifestyle at the heart of the house of Saud’s political bargain with its people. If the royal family cannot deliver the free education and healthcare, cheap housing and easy jobs Saudis are used to, they might shift their political allegiance. . . . 
. . . 
" . . . the economic reform being championed by Mohammed bin Salman as a ­cipher for his ambition is actually really needed by the Saudi state. This matters enormously in the region and for the global economy.
. . . 
"Much of this boils down to whether Mohammed bin Salman is some underestimated genius or a reckless pretender. In the interview with The Economist, he professed himself to be an admirer of Winston Churchill and the wartime British prime minister’s line that opportunities come from crises. The question is, what opportunities will he seek: to advance Saudi Arabia’s interests, or merely his own? Anthony Bubalo is deputy director and research director at the Lowy Institute for International Policy.

"Bin Salman in the few short months since his ailing father ascended the throne has accumulated vast swathes of power. Always the favoured son and his father’s gatekeeper, he has strengthened his position incrementally and on an almost daily basis. "The appointments as defence minister and deputy crown prince were followed by a consolidation of the royal court system which he now controls. He is chairman of the enormously powerful Council for Economic and Development Affairs. He oversees the operation of state-owned Saudi Aramco and runs the kingdom’s sovereign wealth fund PIF (Public Investment Fund) with its assets of $5.3bn. And he strides the world stage meeting Vladimir Putin in Moscow and Barack Obama in Washington. "Needless to say this 30-year-old’s rapid rise within the tight and claustrophobic world of the Saudi royal hierarchy has raised many hackles among his elders. Rumours of a palace coup have swirled for months but remain just that: rumours. "Before the death of King Abdullah in January, Interior Minister Mohammed bin Nayef was thought to be the most powerful man in the kingdom and the one considered in the West to be a trusted and effective ally in the war on extremism.  Highly respected in Washington and London for the pragmatic way in which he dealt with Saudi Arabia’s internal security threats, the 57-year-old bin Nayef has had to tread a careful path since the accession of King Salman. He has had to watch, perhaps with impotent rage, his power base being significantly eroded.
Indeed it is said amongst the cognoscenti in Riyadh that he sleeps with one eye open, wondering what move his youthful rival will next play against him.
. . . 
Mohammed bin Salman has told the West that he too shares their concern with “fighting this disease (extremism) which has damaged the Islamic world.” . . . He, not Mohammed bin Nayef, is the go-to guy on global terror and security. He, in his command centre in Riyadh, and not the interior minister will coordinate a transnational war on Islamist extremists. "In the first blush of the announcement, this may be music to Western ears but it will grate harshly on those of Mohammed bin Nayef. Crown prince he may be, but as his power wanes and his presence diminishes so too do his chances of ever becoming king. "For entirely different reasons the rest of us would do well to be wary too. Given Mohammed bin Salman’s track record thus far in the theatre of war, that being the catastrophe that is Yemen, one can devoutly hope that the alliance remains a paper tiger, a PR stunt and an internal power play.

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/saudiarabia/12029546/Saudi-Arabia-destabilising-Arab-world-German-intelligence-warns.html "It is unusual for the BND spy agency to publicly release such a blunt assessment on a country that is considered an ally of the West. Germany has long-standing political and economic ties with Saudi Arabia.  Saudi Arabia is at risk of becoming a major destabilising influence in the Arab world, German intelligence has warned. "Internal power struggles and the desire to emerge as the leading Arab power threaten to make the key Western ally a source of instability, according to the BND intelligence service.
“The current cautious diplomatic stance of senior members of the Saudi royal family will be replaced by an impulsive intervention policy,” a BND memo widely distributed to the German press reads. "The memo focuses particularly on the role of Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the 30-year-old son of King Salman who was recently appointed deputy crown prince and defence minister.  The concentration of so much power in Prince Mohammed’s hands “harbours a latent risk that in seeking to establish himself in the line of succession in his father’s lifetime, he may overreach,” the memo notes.
. . . 
"Prince Mohammed is believed to want to succeed his father as king, but he is currently second in line to the throne, behind the 80-year-old Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, King Salman’s nephew. "Analysts at the Royal Bank of Canada recenlty described the jockeying for position inside the extensive royal family as “Saudi Arabia’s Game of Thrones”. "The royal family has thousands of members of varying influence and power, and any suggestion Prince Mohammed is trying to move ahead of the crown prince in the line of succession could trigger a dangerous power struggle.

http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1aa6c886-91d1-11e5-bd82-c1fb87bef7af.html#axzz3t6RLCSQG

http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1aa6c886-91d1-11e5-bd82-c1fb87bef7af.html#ixzz3swEd2r1M "The faces of the three leading men of Saudi Arabia stare down at visitors on the streets of Riyadh: King Salman . . . his nephew, crown prince and interior minister, the 56-year-old Prince Mohammed bin Naif; [and] . . .  his favourite son and deputy crown prince, the 30-year-old Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Ask any Saudi where power is concentrated today, however, and they will point to the younger royal. "While the crown prince heads the security council and is credited with repelling the al-Qaeda threat over the past decade, Mohammed bin Salman leads the team working on restructuring the economy. As defence minister, he is the point man on the war in Yemen. Increasingly, he is also his father’s representative on foreign policy, meeting Russia’s Vladimir Putin twice this year and Barack Obama, US president, once. He oversees the operations of the royal court, the most powerful body in the absolute monarchy. Saudi Aramco, the state oil company, as well as the Public Investment Fund, with $5.3bn in assets, are also under his purview. Known for his appetite for detail and data, the young prince has been preparing for his father’s succession for several years. He asked aides to identify areas in need of reform and officials who could be promoted. His spadework led to what analysts describe as a tsunami reshuffle when the monarch assumed the throne in January, on the death of his half-brother King Abdullah. Never in the kingdom’s history had so many royal decrees been issued at once, with dozens of new officials appointed to government. "King Salman also broke with tradition by shifting power to the second generation of princes. Officials speak of a different “tempo” and a willingness to challenge the way things have been done in the past. They argue that the collapse in oil prices should be seen as an opportunity to clean up Saudi finances and diversify the economy. The sidelining of other royals and the accumulation of power in the hands of Mohammed bin Salman have, however, sparked speculation of royal infighting. "Close watchers of the al-Sauds say dissent in the family is real, but that those who have lost out lack the momentum to present a threat to the king. Of greater concern to observers are perceptions of a power struggle between the crown prince and the deputy crown prince.
“Until recently we had several independent power centres in Saudi Arabia, with each senior prince taking decisions, and there was no long-term planning. Now you can have a united decision-making process — but the big concern is that a lot of power is with one prince,” says a Riyadh-based analyst. "As Mohammed bin Salman looks to consolidate his position, the success or failure of his economic plans — and the war in Yemen — will be the yardsticks against which he is measured.  . . .

"The government has slashed public spending by a quarter,. . . . The swingeing $80bn in cuts, bringing spending down to $267bn, will be followed by more austerity next year . . .  Among the priority targets are energy subsidies that cost the treasury 13.2 per cent of gross domestic product, less than half of which go to households. Officials are studying ways of raising non-oil revenues via government fees and a sales tax. But they will broaden existing welfare payments to redistribute money to poor and middle-class Saudis who will be hit hardest by higher electricity, water and petrol prices. "Sceptics say promises of reforms have been made in the past but not delivered. Arbitrary decision-making and the absence of checks and balances in the system also undermine fiscal discipline: when King Salman took over he announced a salary bonus for public sector employees and utilities investment totalling an estimated $30bn. "An ingrained administration that is resistant to change is a further impediment.  . . . 
. . . 
"There are signs that government cuts are damaging business confidence. The private sector, dependent on government spending, is reeling from the sharp retrenchment. “The business community feels there are too many sudden changes in regulations and where we’re going. We need stability in the way we move forward,” says Lama al-Sulaiman, vice-president of the chamber of commerce in Jeddah. "The ruling family, backed by the clerical establishment, have for decades provided jobs and a cheap cost of living for their subjects in return for loyalty to the tribally based, authoritarian system of governance. At the height of the unrest that swept the Arab world, the government showered the population with salary increases and new social spending while cracking down on dissent. Five years on, moves to change the social contract threaten to upend that delicate balance of power as regional threats abound. "Human rights groups say the government continues to use the judicial system to stifle dissent by jailing Shia and pro-democracy activists for anti-government activity, as well as religious crimes such as apostasy or insulting Islam. The number of executions this year has risen to the highest level in two decades, prompting increasing scrutiny of the tough judicial system that mirrors some of the punishments meted out by Isis in the areas it controls in Syria. "The new Saudi regime boosted its popularity in the first months in office with the launch of a bombing campaign in Yemen as Houthi rebels moved south after taking over the capital Sana’a.  . . . Thousands of civilian casualties have raised western concerns about the military campaign, which appears to have settled into a war of attrition, even as public support in Saudi Arabia remains strong. While there is some cautious talk in Riyadh about a truce, the fact is that the Saudis will have to pick up the cost of rebuilding its impoverished neighbour, having spent billions of dollars on helping to demolish it. “There’s a lot of frustration about how they’ve run the campaign,” says a senior western official amid concerns that jihadis have exploited the conflict to widen their presence in the country. "Observers say the Yemen campaign has also reinforced anti-Shia sentiment in Saudi Arabia, where a Shia minority in the eastern province already feels marginalised. “Support for the campaign has been partly built on sectarianism and hatred towards the Shia,” says one Riyadh-based observer.
. . . 
"Delivering a radically different Saudi economy and a more assertive foreign policy are in line with the aspirations of an overwhelmingly young Saudi population: 60 per cent are under the age of 30. A kingdom that is friends with the US, but more self-reliant, one that benefits from oil wealth but does not rely solely on it, are popular aspirations. "But the first test facing the monarchy lies in implementation, whether on the economic front or on security. Saudi businessmen remember bitterly earlier periods of low oil prices and promises of diversification that were abandoned when the outlook for crude improved. The Yemen war, meanwhile, has not inspired greater confidence in Saudi military capabilities among its allies. "The monarchy must also manage the impact of change on the relationship between rulers and ruled. Saudis are subjected to restrictions on free speech but they are active users of social media and public opinion cannot be ignored. There is growing awareness of corruption and the excessive spending of the royal elite, which could derail attempts to impose more austerity. "Saudi Arabia is in desperate need of reform but the sweeping changes envisaged take the kingdom into uncharted territory, creating demands for popular representation, which has no place in the monarchy’s vision of the future.

"The deteriorating health of King Salman, on the throne for less than a year, is fueling a bitter succession battle in Saudi Arabia that has drawn in royals across generations and political stripes.  King Salman reportedly was hospitalized earlier in October for what was believed to be a condition brought about by his worsening Alzheimer’s disease. In his “temporary absence,” palace insiders say, the monarch’s two crown princes took charge.  The 79-year-old monarch has since returned to work, meeting with US Secretary of State John Kerry and other foreign officials in recent weeks. "But longtime observers say what palace officials refuse to admit publicly: King Salman is unlikely to continue his reign unaided. As a result, bitter infighting over his succession has begun and has exposed a sharp division between conservative and reformist branches in the royal family.
. . . 
"In Salman’s absence, palace insiders say, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef took charge of interior security and Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the ailing king’s son, handled foreign affairs, economic, and defense portfolios.  Yet because of Mohammed bin Salman’s unfettered access to his father’s advisers and his role in leading the war in Yemen, palace insiders say the young prince has assumed greater responsibility and at times has served as “de facto head of state.”
“All final decisions pass first through Prince Mohammed bin Salman,” one royal court official said. "Under the current line of succession established by Salman, Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, 56, would be next in line to the throne, followed by Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 30.  Both princes have supporters within and outside the kingdom. Mohammed bin Nayef has built ties with Washington by positioning Saudi Arabia as an ally in fighting terrorism, while Prince Mohammed bin Salman has styled himself as an economic liberalizer. 
. . . 
"Still, battle over control of the kingdom is not a simple two-horse race. According to longtime Saudi observers, a wider struggle between reformers and conservatives is underway within the 271-year-old House of Saud. Reformists within the royal family quickly soured on King Salman. . . . “The Saudi government and Saudi Royal family have always been a balance between conservative forces and calls for change, and King Salman has swung in favor of the conservatives – this may have caused a backlash,” says Frederic Wehrey, senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace’s Middle East Program. "Reformists reportedly also reject Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who they fear will continue his father’s legacy. Instead, they favor another candidate for the throne: Prince Ahmed bin Abdulaziz, son of the late Saudi founder Abdulaziz Ibn Saud, who they claim by birthright holds a more legitimate claim to the throne. "In a rare public display of royal infighting, an unnamed prince published an open letter in September calling for King Salman’s dismissal, extolling Prince Ahmed’s credentials. Reformists say Prince Ahmed showed leniency towards political prisoners during his term as deputy interior minister. "Among those clamoring for change in the palace are royals who object to King Salman’s unorthodox succession plan, which leapfrogged 11 of Abdulaziz Ibn Saud’s surviving sons (Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef are both grandsons of the late patriarch.) “It has long been an established rule in Saudi that the greatest threat to the ruler’s power comes from his first constituency: the royal family,” says Gregory Gause, a Gulf expert and professor of international affairs at Texas A&M University.  “Since the 1960s, the way of avoiding conflict was power-sharing among a set of princes," he says. "Salman has upset the tradition by consolidating a lot of power in those two princes and now we are seeing this playing out.” "A name being put forward by some conservatives is Prince Muqrin bin Abdulaziz, the former head of Saudi intelligence services. In April he was removed from the post of crown prince and the line of succession by King Salman. "The removal of a Saudi king by disgruntled royals is not without precedent. In 1964, a group of Abdulaziz Ibn Saud’s sons forced then-King Saud, their brother, to abdicate because of his reckless spending and erratic behavior.  While such an internal coup could occur, it would only take place under a broad agreement, observers say. When faced with external challenges, such as what Saudi Arabia sees as a growing threat posed by regional rival Iran, Saudi royals tend to close ranks in order to ensure stability, at least in the short term. “At the end of the day, this is a family that closes ranks in the face of external threats,” Mr. Wehrey said. “There may be jockeying for power within the royal family – but even that jockeying has its limits.”

Upon further reflection, I'm updating my forecast to give more weight to the possibility that King Salman will survive to June 1, 2016.  When Saudi Kings develop terminal disease, they don't have to worry about hospital length-of-stay.  Salman's predecessor may have been hospitalized for nearly a year before he finally succumbed.  It seems more likely that Salman is not hospitalized, and therefore not in any immediate crisis.  He may be getting what amounts to a nursing home level of care. From all reports, King Salman Bin Abduazziz al Saud is in poor health at age 80.  Saudi Kings have survived to an average age of 78.8 years.  Of course, the N is small and the mean is skewed by the assassination of King Faisal at the age of 69.  If King Salman lives to June of 2016, he will exceed the average life of Saudi Kings by only 2-3%.  Saudi royals frequently have cardiovascular disease.  Salman is partially paralyzed after a stroke.  He had spinal surgery in 2011.  There are rumors that he may have dementia, or possibly some type of aphasia.  He may be unable to function as King even though his reign began just this past January.  In April, Mohammed bin Nayef was named Crown Prince and Mohammed bin Salman was named Deputy Crown Prince, so the line of succession is clear.  Apparently, day-to-day operations have been transferred to these two.  King Salman himself may be in the equivalent of a nursing home situation.  The average survival time in full custodial care tends to be about 3 years.  So I think there may be some reasonable chance he will survive to June 2016, continue to be the nominal King until he dies, and later be succeeded by Mohammed bin Nayef.

• I challenged dominich to participate in a public brainstorming with us, so it is only fair that I do likewise. Here are just a few items I suggest are at least interesting to consider:
1) I believe we can safely assume that "financial assets" are those that, upon instruction, can be converted into cash in some reasonable time. Generally liquid assets, cash and near-cash equivalents. Let's just say everything but hard assets (physical property).
2) Reports have it that the Saudi fortune, the so-called sovereign fund, which is entwined with the Kingdom, has experienced financial asset redemptions of anywhere from 12.5 to 20% over the course of the past twelve months. That is, simplistically speaking, the Saudi royals are calling their brokers with instructions to sell shares and send them the money. These redemptions, presumably, are going to expenses. The Saudis are, apparently, spending money far more rapidly than they are bringing it in.
3) Simultaneously, we have the story that the Saudi "strategy" of flooding the market with cheap oil is oh-so "successful." Everything must be done to preserve "market share." Well, if you just stop to think about it, the basic idea of a market share strategy in a natural resource commodity market is rather ludicrous. Sure, there are the logistical relationships, and the financial pressure placed on competitors. etc. But a natural resource commodity market has certain characteristics. a) The commodities, unlike, say, a factory that is tooled to produce automobiles, do not go away when the owners go bankrupt. New owners come in, but the commodities, in this case oil, remain. b) In such a commodities market, buyers take whatever is offered by whomever it is offered. The fact that you sold me oil last month at the best price (for which I paid and thanked you) should have little impact on whom I buy oil from this month. A marketshare strategy in a natural resource commodities market is, frankly, baloney. Since (Units Sold [Market Share] x Price/Unit) = Income is the inescapable economic equation, we see that this strategy of maximizing/maintaining market share is only half the equation. The rational goal is to maximize income, not market share. Rather than suggesting the Saudis are irrational, I suggest that the story of maximizing marketshare be recognized as only a component in some larger scheme; and considered by itself as only a ruse, a cover story. But a cover story for what? At the surface, it would be a cover story for the Saudis' massive depletion of their financial assets. Lacking such a story, the world would have wondered where the Saudis were suddenly taking such a large percentage of their wealth. They are doing something with it, but what? What expenses have they converted their redemptions into? Yes, there are expenses of the Kingdom -- but what goes elsewhere in the wash? What activities would require such massively large secretive funding?
4) Just for speculative consideration, couched in pure hyperbole for emphasis: What is it that the Saudis want so desperately that they are willing to spend hundreds of billions in bribery to obtain? And, who would be in a position to provide it for them? (There is, of course, the more mundane but only sightly less dramatic explanation for a marketshare strategy in a commodity market: to secretly acquire, after bankruptcy, through covert agents, the assets (the oil rights) of those competitive firms driven into bankruptcy.  This is the classic consolidation scheme that was used in early 20th century America. The problem with this scenario is that the oil assets are only just beginning to turn over now, slowly; so the Saudi financial assets would not have been required in such large quantities as have already been redeemed.) I simply do not buy the marketshare strategy at all. As to King Salman, he inherited the marketshare strategy (and whatever underlying scheme it is designed to obscure). The rumors of palace intrigue, and the implicit threats contained therein, are to keep him in line. His life is in some danger so long as the role of Saudi King is required for orchestration of the scheme. Only completion of the scheme or revelation of its secretive nature would remove the danger. I'm guessing that he continues to play the game.

I don't think that a new king is particularly likely. A couple of factors that I considered: 1) Historical trend. Saudi Arabia has only had seven monarchs since 1932: Ibn Saud (1932-53), Saud (1953-64), Faisal (64-75) Khalid (1975-82), Fahd (1982-2005), Abdullah (2005-15), and Salman (2015-Present). Excluding Salman, the average reign of a Saudi King has been over 13 years. Most kings have also reigned until their death. The exceptions are Faisal, who was assassinated, and Saud, who was forced to abdicate.  2) King Salman in currently 79 years old. Using U.S. social security actuarial tables as a proxy (presumably Salman has access to some pretty top-notch doctors), the probability of a 79 year old male dying within the year is only about 5 per cent or so. However, it is worth noting that some outlets have reported that Salman is in ill health, though it is not entirely clear what ails him.  3) Given the size of the House of Saud (which has thousands of members), some inter-family politicking is to be expected, particularly at a time when there is less money to spread around. That being said, it isn't clear that the letters calling for the replacement of Salman and his heir are actually from a member of the royal family.  4) Salman and his heirs still appear to enjoy the support of a number of powerful actors, including the clerical establishment and the military. The rest of the royal family has also been relatively supportive (or at least silent). According to the Guardian, only one senior royal has publically endorsed the letter calling for Salman's replacement. The past record of Saudi Arabian rule  - since 1975 at least - suggests a palace coup is unlikely (admittedly: some special, and effectively unprecedented circumstances now pertain - not just with regard to the complex foreign relations dimension, but also with regard to the change of generations that the current crown prince, Mohammed bin Nayef, represents). Apart from the need of the regime to maintain appearances, dignity, etc, which a palace coup might threaten, such a measure might hint too overtly at weaknesses in the regime, and thus give succour to domestic (violent) opponents. The precedent of Abdullah, while Crown Prince, acting in many regards as de facto King, for several years while Fahd was incapacitated, suggests a modus operandi should Salman's health rapidly deteriorate - - - or as even as a potential means of cover of a de facto, but discreet, change of power within the regime. This leaves the possibility of the death of Salman within the period under question. While this can't be ruled out, he is aged 79.  His two most recent predecessors comfortably outlived him: Abdullah lived to 89, Fahd to 84,. However, Khalid to only 69, Faisal also to 69 (when he was assassinated, by a member ofthe family). Solid information about Salman's health - or, specifically, of any ailments that could be considered life-threatening in the short term, before next June, - appears to be lacking.
